title: Contributing
text:
We are seeking contributors to this manual. Please contact Val Zimmer for more information.



We develop the content using RStudio, build the book using Quarto (via RStudio), and collaborate and publish using GitHub (also via RStudio).


To contribute, you must do the following, and it should only take about 20 minutes to complete:

Install R and RStudio
Both R and RStudio should be available in the Software Center (for Windows 10) or Company Portal (for Windows 11) – if you don’t see them in your Software Center/Company Portal or you have issues/questions during the instillation process, please send a request to the DIT HelpDesk and they can help you install them.
Also see these step by step instructions on how to install these programs – you will only need to go through steps 1 and 2
If you are new to R, it would also be helpful if you could review the Getting Started Module so you can begin to familiarize yourself with the fundamentals of the program.
Install Quarto
Quarto download and install instructions
Create a GitHub Account
Create your free personal account GitHub account
Tips on choosing your username
Download and Install Git
Follow your operating system’s normal Git installation process. Note: you will not see an application called Git listed but if the installation process completed it was likely successful, and we will confirm together.

title: Bathymetry: Field Measurement
text:
This section describes how to use the ADCP for bathymetry measurements in the field. The section describes data collection in a stationary body of water, not for streamflow measurements. add section on collecting bathymetry data in moving water?



install software
check equipment











software operation
note-taking

title: Bathymetry: Field Measurement
text:
install software
check equipment

title: Bathymetry: Field Measurement
text:
software operation
note-taking

title: ADCP Operations
text:
An Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler, or ADCP, uses sound waves to measure depth and the direction and speed of moving water. Frequency determines the depth and precision of the measured data, with higher frequencies having higher precision and lower frequencies with greater depth range. The ADCP is mounted on a platform on the surface of the water and coupled with a compass so that the instrument knows which direction the water is moving. Our ADCP is paired with a GPS-RTK (global positioning system - real time kinematic) with an accuracy of about 2 cm.
The ADCP is used in rivers that are deep or large rivers that cannot be waded safely - it may also be used in rivers during the winter, when flows are higher or there are hazards downstream. The ADCP requires water depths of at least 1 ft (2 or more feet is better). The ADCP can also be used to measure the depth to the bottom of a lake (or possibly a river) and map bathymetry.

This section is aimed at training staff on how to use the ADCP and process the data. For streamflow measurements in wadeable streams, please see the flow measurement section.


The Sontek M9 works to a depth of ~40 m (130 ft), with velocities up to about 20 m/s (66 ft/s). However, actual depths in the field may be limited by vegetation, suspended sediments, uneven topography, or other impediments. The motor, tethering system, moving particles, or the presence of standing waves (rapids) may limit operation in fast-moving water.



There is a set of 4 3.0 MHz and 4 1.0 MHz transducers for velocity profiling, and one 0.5 MHz vertical beam for maximum depth.

title: ADCP Operations
text: The Sontek M9 works to a depth of ~40 m (130 ft), with velocities up to about 20 m/s (66 ft/s). However, actual depths in the field may be limited by vegetation, suspended sediments, uneven topography, or other impediments. The motor, tethering system, moving particles, or the presence of standing waves (rapids) may limit operation in fast-moving water.

title: ADCP Operations
text: There is a set of 4 3.0 MHz and 4 1.0 MHz transducers for velocity profiling, and one 0.5 MHz vertical beam for maximum depth.

title: Bathymetry: Getting Started
text:
This section describes how to get started using the ADCP for bathymetry measurements.


Bathymetry measurements with the ADCP require the HYPACK MAX software to collect data in the field and to process the data back in the lab. HYPACK MAX
Documentation for HYPACK MAX is found on the HYPACK_MAX sharepoint page on the HYPACK software website.
We have a single software license that must be shared. This license will work indefinitely, but software updates and technical support are subscription-based, and currently active to ~mid 2025.


Put in a help desk ticket to DIT have have the software activated in your Software Center (type software center into the search bar, shown below). You may wish to check for updates since Sept 2024 before doing so on the HYPACK software website. Install all files onto your computer.




We have a single “soft license” for sharing, and it is important that staff are diligent in deactivating the license when not in use. The license deactivates automatically after 90 days. The process for obtaining access to the license (aka the Activation Key) is TBD (working with DIT 2024-09-16).
To activate the license, open up HYPACK License Manager, select Activate/Deactivate Soft License, allow the HYPACK Soft License Wizard to open, and click Activate your license. Select Activate Online (doing so offline may cause issues). Put in the Activation Key and click Activate.

To deactivate the license, open up HYPACK License Manager and select Activate/Deactivate Soft License.




connect computer to the M9 river surveyor instrument to check function



practice driving the rQPOD and collecting good data before going into the field at a project site.

title: Streamflow: Getting Started
text:
This section describes how to get started using the ADCP, which is used in deep or large rivers, or in smaller rivers with high flows. The ADCP requires water depths of at least 1 ft (2 or more feet is better). For streamflow measurements in wadeable streams, please see the flow measurement section.


Documentation for RiverSurveyor Live! is found on the RiverSurveyor Live sharepoint page on the official software website. No license is needed for this software.


Put in a help desk ticket to DIT have have the software activated in your Software Center (type software center into the search bar, shown below). You may wish to check for updates since Sept 2024 before doing so on the River Surveyor software websitee. Install all files onto your computer.

title: Travel
text:
Exempt, excluded, and represented state employees may be eligible for the reimbursement of authorized out-of-pocket expenses that are reasonably, actually, and necessarily incurred as a result of conducting state business.


The Division has several vehicles available for field work. Please see DWR Employee Resources Fleet Page for up-to-date information about using fleet vehicles.




Travel Pocket Guide (Intranet) - can only access on VPN 
CalTravelStore / Concur (where you book your travel)
CalATERS Global (where you submit your travel expense claims [TEC] for reimbursement)
CalHR Manual - Allowances and Travel Reimbursements Section
CalHR Webpage - Travel Reimbursements 
Water Board’s Travel Page (Intanet) - can only access on VPN 
Travel Forms (Intranet) - can only access on VPN 




CalTravelStore New User Registration
For new users to be added to CalTravelStore to begin making reservations, contact the CalATERS Travel Help Desk.
Email: CalATERS-Travel@waterboards.ca.gov
Phone: (916) 341-5036
The CalATERS Travel Help Desk can provide assistance or answer questions about making travel reservations, recommendations while traveling, and asking for reimbursement when you return. The Travel Help Desk for the Waterboards is comprised of the Travel Unit staff in the Accounting Office as part of the Division of Administrative Services. 
Visit CalTravelStore, a self-serve site for all government business travel needs. Travelers are able to make reservations for lodging, airfare, rental car & rail fare through Concur which is personalized to meet the needs of State government travelers.



Get approval to travel; if traveling for training or a conference - see the Training section for forms that must be completed and approved before booking travel arrangements
Book your travel (flights, hotels, rental cars) using the CalTravelStore / Concur system.
Travel to and from your destination and save all receipts (see Tip #2 below for details)
Submit your Travel Expense Claim for reimbursement - this is currently a 3-step process:

Gather your receipts and complete your TEC in CalATERS Global - save a PDF of the TEC for use in Step 2 below
Complete the Adobe Sign process to get you TEC digitally signed and approved
Once you received a digitally signed version of your TEC, submit that and all of your required original receipts to Accounting. This can be done by dropping of your TEC package in-person in the CalEPA building, or mailing it in using the address provided on page 1 of your TEC.






Ask your Supervisor for a copy of the Adobe Sign Instruction guide - this will walk you through the 3-step TEC process above in more detail.
Receipts should be submitted for every item of expense of $25 or more. When receipts are not required to be submitted with a travel expense claim, it is the employee’s responsibility to maintain receipts and records of their actual expenses. Read more information on reimbursement here.  
Know your reimbursement rates! State employees may be eligible to receive reimbursement for expenses such as:

Method of travel (transportation)
Meals and incidentals
Short-term lodging
Out-of-state travel
Out-of-country travel
Personal vehicle mileage 
Other actual and necessary business and/or travel costs incurred while conducting official state business

Airline reservations should be made no more than 30 days prior to the expected travel dates.

Department of General Services (DGS) recommends booking flights between 21 to 30 days prior to travel.
Frequent travelers should book non-refundable fares since there is a high probability that the unused funds will be used for future travel within the expiration period.
Non-frequent travelers should book non-refundable fares if the trips dates are fixed and there is a low probability of a change in plans.






CalATERS Travel Help Desk
Phone: (916) 341-5036
Email: CalATERS-Travel@waterboards.ca.gov

title: Procurement
text:
Please work with DWRs’s procurement lead to coordinate your supplies purchases. The process changes frequently. It can take several months (up to 12 months or more) from time of placing order to receiving goods, so plan in advance if possible.

title: Data to Store

title: Inspiration
text:
Inspiration
The impetus for developing this manual began in 2024 when some of us participated in the Water Boards Openscapes Champions Cohort.
This Manual was started with help from the folks behind the, SWAMP Manual, who generously shared their time and code to get us started!
We are also inspired by the following sources:

Openscapes and their Approach Guide
NOAA Fisheries (NMFS) Open Science Resource Book
The Fay Lab Manual

title: Stream Gaging Team
text:
Stream gaging and bathymetry measurements are currently being done by a variety of units for different projects, mostly within the Division of Water Rights. Division equipment is internally on Sharepoint.








Name
Project(s)
Expertise




Val Zimmer
Clear Lake Hitch
Flow measurement, Rating curve development, equipment, data management

title: Administrative goodies
text:
Administrative goodies
This section contains resources to make administrative tasks a bit more straightforward.

title: Streamflow: Data Processing
text:
This section describes how to acquire and process streamflow data collected with the Sontek M9. Data management and rating curve generation is the same as that done for streamflow measurements collected by other methods. Please refer to add section here.


we may need to work with DIT for these software(s) to work.
The USGS publishes free software to help with ADCP data processing. Two recommended softwares are QRev, which is used to compute discharge, and extrap that is used to extrapolate measurements. USGS software requires data to be in Matlab format, which can be exported from the Sontek M9.



https://www.usgs.gov/hydroacoustics/moving-boat-measurements

title: Streamflow: Data Processing
text:
we may need to work with DIT for these software(s) to work.
The USGS publishes free software to help with ADCP data processing. Two recommended softwares are QRev, which is used to compute discharge, and extrap that is used to extrapolate measurements. USGS software requires data to be in Matlab format, which can be exported from the Sontek M9.

title: Streamflow: Data Processing
text: https://www.usgs.gov/hydroacoustics/moving-boat-measurements

title: Streamflow: Field Measurement
text:
This section describes field measurements and procedures for the ADCP, which is used in deep or large rivers, or in smaller rivers with high flows. The ADCP requires water depths of at least 1 ft (2 or more feet is better). For streamflow measurements wadeable streams, please see add section here..
Standard operating procedures, including (general) site selection, note-taking, safety, and data management, follows the same general principles for both ADCP measurements and measurements made by wading in the stream using a flowtracker or other similar instrument. Please refer to add section here.
This page deals with the specifics of collecting good streamflow measurements using the Sontek M9 using either a bridge or shore tether or driving the rQPOD motor.
Sontek has a video training series on collecting data with the Sontek ADCP.



install software
check equipment

title: Streamflow: Field Measurement

install software
check equipment

title: Streamflow: Field Measurement
Bathymetry: Data Processing
text:
Bathymetry: Data Processing
Bathymetry data need to be processed with HYPACK MAX software.

title: Equipment CheckList
text:
The ADCP equipment falls into four major buckets: the sensor, the GPS system, the platform, and the motor for the platform. There are many small pieces in the system and you are encouraged to put everything together and check operation before heading out into the field.
The complete setup with components is shown in the figure below.



Here is a list of items that were purchased in 2024 when the equipment was brand new. The equipment must be reserved and checked out on the DWR Reserve Equipment page.




charge rQPOD batteries and rQPOD radio controller
get 32 AA batteries and spares for M9
gather equipment and turn it on to check that is it functioning
review the manuals and equipment list




The following equipment should be gathered and brought to the field when doing ADCP surveys:

trucks and all truck safety equipment
SPOT beacon (input important numbers before leaving)
Personal safety equipment, including life jackets, orange safety vests, and good footwear.



Streamflow measurements with the ADCP require equipment as listed below and the RiverSurveyor Live! software installed on a field computer. The system consists of a platform, a GPS system, and the instrument itself, a Sontek M9. The ADCP can either be controlled with an rQPOD remote-controlled motor, or tethered off a bridge or with ropes from either side.

The River Surveyor (Sontek M9) manuals can be found on the riversurveyor sharepoint and at the Sontek website.

Torrent board, with

fins and fin keys
tow-strap plus 100 ft rope (for tethering)

OPTIONAL rQPOD remote-controlled motor system (for untethered)
River Survey M9 with xx-pin cable (to plug into RTK GPS)
RTK GPS Base Station

base station with 16 AA batteries and tripod mount
tripod
GPS antenna, cables, rod, and tripod mount, with screws
telemetry antenna with cable(s)

RTK GPS Rover

rover station with 16 AA batteries
GPS antenna, cables, rod, and board mount, with screws
telemetry antenna with cable(s)





Everything on the streamflow adcp list plus the rQPOD (and all pieces) and HYPACK MAX software with software license.

The rQPOD is shown above, and consists of a motor with two thrusters and radio controller. Information about assembling and using rQPOD can be found on the rQPOD sharepoint and the manufacturers’s website. Batteries must be charged for the radio controller and motor! The rQPOD is kept in a large black case, which should contain:

rQPOD remote controlled motor (in white box)
two thrusters with cables and (red/green) skid guards
magnetic pen (to turn motor on)
TORX drive and box of screw for motors, skid guard, and housing (assemble!) and fin key
2 drone (Lipo) batteries and battery charger, in orange case
Radiomaster controller




The following items are consumables associated with the ADCP. You may also need to order replacements for lost or broken parts, such as screws.

AA batteries (32)
Krytox GPL205 grease for the screws (if dried out)
20 Amp glasses fuse 6.3 mm x 32 mm (250V)

title: Equipment CheckList
text: Here is a list of items that were purchased in 2024 when the equipment was brand new. The equipment must be reserved and checked out on the DWR Reserve Equipment page.

title: Equipment CheckList
text:
charge rQPOD batteries and rQPOD radio controller
get 32 AA batteries and spares for M9
gather equipment and turn it on to check that is it functioning
review the manuals and equipment list

title: Equipment CheckList
text:
The following equipment should be gathered and brought to the field when doing ADCP surveys:

trucks and all truck safety equipment
SPOT beacon (input important numbers before leaving)
Personal safety equipment, including life jackets, orange safety vests, and good footwear.

The system consists of a platform, a GPS system, and the instrument itself, a Sontek M9. title: Welcome!
text:
Welcome!
This manual is under construction.
This is an online reference and resource written by and for the Division of Water Rights at the California State Water Resources Control Board (State Water Board).
This manual is written to help train staff in stream gaging, instream flow measurement, and bathymetry measurement. Topics may include equipment, preparation for field work, data collection, data processing, and data storage. It is a place to document institutional knowledge and provide references to available resources.
This Quarto book is an open, living, and continuously iterating resource. If you have suggestions for additions or revisions you think should be incorporated into this book, please follow the guidance provided in the Contributing chapter.
